Package edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.logic

Class Clause<A extends Atom>

java.lang.Object
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.logic.Conjunction<A>
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.logic.Clause<A>
Type Parameters:
A - the type of this clause's arguments
All Implemented Interfaces:
Expression, Logical, Proposition, Simplifiable, Typed, Countable, Serializable, Comparable<Logical>, Iterable<A>
public class Clause<A extends Atom> extends Conjunction<A>
A clause is a conjunction of atoms. Clauses play a key role in disjunctive normal form expressions and have some additional logic for efficiently adding and removing atoms. The atom of a clause are always in their natural order.
Author:
Stephen G. Ware
See Also:

  • Field Details

    • NULL

      public static final Clause<Atom> NULL
      The null clause is a empty clause which is logically equivalent to false. Though an empty conjunction would normally be logically equivalent to true (see the empty clause), this object exists for situations where a clause object is needed that is trivially false, such as when an event has a contradictory effect. Atoms cannot be added or removed from the null clause (that is, adding atoms to or removing atoms from the null clause always results in the null clause itself).

    • EMPTY

      public static final Clause<Atom> EMPTY
      The empty clause is clause with zero atoms which is logically equivalent to true.

    • toEffect

      public Clause<Effect> toEffect()
      Description copied from interface: Expression
      Converts an expression whose type is boolean to disjunctive normal form (DNF) suitable to appear in the deterministic effect of an event. Because effects must be deterministic, this process must result in a disjunction of no more than one conjunctive clause whose atoms are effects. Because there will only be at most one clause, that clause is returned instead of a disjunction. If no clauses would be returned (in other words, if false would be returned), the null clause is returned.
      Specified by:
      toEffect in interface Expression
      Overrides:
      toEffect in class Conjunction<A extends Atom>
      Returns:
      a conjunctive clause whose atoms are effects

    • isPrecondition

      public boolean isPrecondition()
      Tests whether every atom in this clause is a precondition.
      Returns:
      true if every atom is a precondition or if there are no atoms, false otherwise

    • isEffect

    • add

      public Clause<A> add(Clause<A> clause)
      Adds all atoms from this clause and the given clause together to form a new clause. The resulting clause will not necessarily have as many atoms as both clauses combined because the clause is simplified as it is built. For example, if merging the clauses would create a contradiction, perhaps because an atom from this clause negates an atom in the given clause, the null clause will be returned. If atoms from the two clauses can be combined, they will be.
      Parameters:
      clause - the clause to combine with this clause
      Returns:
      a simplified clause resulting from combining this clause and the given clause

    • remove

      public Clause<A> remove(A atom)
      Removes an atom from this clause. See remove(Clause) for details on removing from clauses.
      Parameters:
      atom - the atom to be removed
      Returns:
      a simplified clause resulting from removing the atom

    • remove

      public Clause<A> remove(Clause<A> clause)
      Removes atoms from this clause if they appear, or if a more specific version appears, in the given clause, or returns the null clause if an atom in the given clause contradict this clause. Let a be some atom in this clause and b be an atom in the given clause. If a and b are the same, a will be removed. If a and b can be combined, and the result is b, this means b was more specific than a, and a will be removed. If they can be combined and the result is something other than b, then a will not removed. If a negates b, this method returns the null clause.

      This method can be used to regress this clause over the given clause. This clause can be viewed as a condition (such as the precondition of an event, though this clause does not need to have precondition atoms) and the given clause can be viewed as changes made (such as the effect of an event, though the given clause does not need to have effect atoms). Regressing this clause means removing the conditions from this clause which the given clause could have caused. So if this clause has the condition that f > 3 and we regress the effect f = 4 (which is more specific and satisfied the condition), the condition would be removed. However, if we regress the effect f = 2 (which contradicts the condition), than there is no way that effect could have led to a condition where f > 3, so this method returns the null clause.

      Parameters:
      clause - the clause whose atoms will be removed from this clause
      Returns:
      this clause, with atoms removed if they (or more specific versions) appear in the given clause, or the null clause if some atom in the given clause contradicts an atom in this clause
